title: Ethan’s Section Material
text: This is a GitHub site, designed to host material created by Ethan Marzban for his teaching duties at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:

\]

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Hello!

A Quick Introduction

Hello! My name is Ethan (he/him), and I will be taking over from Sirui.

I am a sixth year PhD; this is my fourth time with this course (including having been the Instructor once :) )

My Office Hours: Wednesdays, 11:30 am - 12:30 pm in South Hall 5607F (Inside the PSTAT Main Office, on the Fifth Floor of South Hall)

These have been posted to Canvas as well.

My Email: epmarzban@pstat.ucsb.edu (please allow a 24 business hour response time)

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Distributions

What Makes Them Unique?






Question



What uniquely determines a distribution?



One of three things:


An MGF (Moment-Generating Function)
A CDF/CMF (Cumulative Distribution/Mass Function)
A PDF/PMF (Probability Density/Mass Function)

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Distributions

What Makes Them Unique?
For Example:

If I tell you X is a random variable with MGF MX(t) = et2, you can immediately tell me that X follows a Normal Distribution with mean 0 and variance 2.
If I tell you Y is a random variable with density given by fY(y) = 2e-2y for y > 0 and 0 otherwise, you can immediately tell me that Y follows an Exponential Distribution with scale parameter 1/2.


Not all distributions have names, but they can still be uniquely defined; e.g. a random variable Z with density fZ(z) = π cos(π z) for 0 ≤ z ≤ 1 and 0 otherwise

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Transformations






Goal



Given a random variable Y and a function h, we wish to identify the distribution of U := h(Y).



Can be accomplished by finding:

The MGF of U (MGF Method)
The CDF/CMF of U (CDF Method)
The PDF/PMF of U (Inverse Transformation Method, or Change of Variable)



This is essentially the roadmap for the next few lectures/weeks in this course!

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Transformations
Might seem abstract… but quite applicable!

Unit Conversion: the temperature C in Centigrade at a randomly-selected location in a city follows some distribution; what is the distribution of temperatures F as measured in Fahrenheit?

Example of a univariate transformation; i.e. a transformation of only one random variable

Data Summary: given an i.i.d. collection of random variables, what is the distribution of the sample mean? Or, the sample variance? Or, the sample maximum?

Examples of multivariate transformations; i.e. transformations involving multiple random variables

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Moment Generating Functions






Definition



The Moment Generating Function (MGF) for a random variable Y is defined as \[ M_Y(t) := \mathbb{E}[e^{tY}] \]



Question for you: When do we compute an MGF as a sum, and when do we compute it as an integral?








Properties of MGFs




\(M_{aY + b}(t) = e^{bt} M_Y(at)\)
For independent \(X\) and \(Y\), \(M_{X + Y}(t) = M_X(t) \cdot M_Y(t)\)
Moment-Generating Property: \(M_Y^{(n)}(0) = \E[Y^n]\)

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
Moment Generating Functions

Example

Partially Worked-Out Example: Y ~ Exp(β) (note the parametrization being used in 120B is different from that in 120A!)


\[ M_Y(t) = \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{ty} \cdot \frac{1}{\beta} e^{-y/\beta} \ \mathrm{d}y = \frac{1}{\beta} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-\left(\frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)y}  \ \mathrm{d}y \]


This integral is finite only when \((\frac{1}{\beta} - t) > 0\); i.e. when \(t < 1/\beta\). When it is finite: \[\begin{align}
  \class{fragment}{{} M_Y(t)}
&\class{fragment}{{} = \frac{1}{\beta} \cdot {\color{blue} \frac{1}{\left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)} } \cdot  \int_{0}^{\infty} {\color{blue} \left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right) }  e^{-\left(\frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)y}  \ \mathrm{d}y}  \\[1mm]
&\class{fragment}{{} = \frac{1}{\beta} \cdot  \frac{1}{\left( \frac{1}{\beta} - t \right)} = \frac{1}{1 - \beta t}}   \\[3mm]
\end{align}\]

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
CDF Method

General Idea: Write \(F_U(u) := \mathbb{P}(U \leq u)\)

Main task is to write the event \(\{U \leq u\}\) in terms of Y, since everything about Y is known.
My advice: a picture is worth a thousand words!

title: PSTAT 120B: Mathematical Statistics
text:
CDF Method

Recall the example from lecture: X ~ Unif[-1, 1] and Y = X2
